content.title: Electric Current ($I$)
content.body:
Electric current is the rate of flow of electric charges through a conductor.

**Formula:** $I = \frac{Q}{t}$
**Unit:** Ampere (A). 
1 Ampere = 1 Coulomb / 1 Second.

**Direction:** Conventionally, the direction of current is taken as the direction of flow of positive charges (opposite to the flow of electrons).
content.analogy: Current is like the flow of water in a pipe. The amount of water passing a point every second is the 'current'.

content.instruction: Examiners often ask to 'Define the unit of current':
content.exactPhrase: One Ampere is constituted by the flow of one Coulomb of charge per second. It is measured by an instrument called an Ammeter, which is always connected in series in a circuit.

content.title: Potential Difference ($V$)
content.body:
The work done to move a unit charge from one point to another in an electric circuit.

**Formula:** $V = \frac{W}{Q}$
**Unit:** Volt (V). 
Measured by a **Voltmeter**, which is always connected in **parallel** across the points where the potential difference is to be measured.
content.analogy: Potential difference is like the 'pressure' that pushes the water through the pipe. No pressure difference = no flow.

content.title: Ohm's Law
content.body:
At a constant temperature, the current ($I$) flowing through a conductor is directly proportional to the potential difference ($V$) across its ends.

**Equation:** $V \propto I \Rightarrow V = IR$
Where $R$ is the **Resistance** of the conductor.

content.instruction: A 3-mark favorite. Mention all four factors:
content.exactPhrase: The resistance ($R$) of a uniform metallic conductor is: 1. Directly proportional to its length ($L$). 2. Inversely proportional to its area of cross-section ($A$). 3. Dependent on the nature of the material. 4. Dependent on the temperature. Formula: $R = \rho \frac{L}{A}$ (where $\rho$ is resistivity).

content.title: Resistivity ($\rho$)
content.body:
Resistivity is a characteristic property of the material. It does not change with the change in length or area of the conductor.

- **Metals/Alloys:** Low resistivity ($10^{-8}$ to $10^{-6} \Omega m$).
- **Insulators:** High resistivity ($10^{12}$ to $10^{17} \Omega m$).
- **Alloys:** Used in heating devices because they have higher resistivity and do not oxidize (burn) at high temperatures.

content.title: Series Combination
content.body:
When resistors are joined end-to-end.
1. **Current:** Same through each resistor.
2. **Potential Difference:** Divided ($V = V_1 + V_2 + V_3$).
3. **Equivalent Resistance:** $R_s = R_1 + R_2 + R_3$

Total resistance is always **greater** than the individual resistances.

content.title: Parallel Combination
content.body:
When resistors are connected between the same two points.
1. **Current:** Divided ($I = I_1 + I_2 + I_3$).
2. **Potential Difference:** Same across each resistor.
3. **Equivalent Resistance:** $\frac{1}{R_p} = \frac{1}{R_1} + \frac{1}{R_2} + \frac{1}{R_3}$

Total resistance is always **lesser** than the smallest individual resistance.

content.instruction: Explain why we use parallel circuits at home:
content.exactPhrase: Parallel circuits are used in domestic wiring because: 1. If one appliance fails, others continue to work. 2. Each appliance gets the same voltage. 3. Each appliance can be operated with its own independent switch.

content.title: Joule's Law of Heating
content.body:
When an electric current flows through a resistor, heat is produced.

**Formula:** $H = I^2Rt$
**Law Statement:** Heat produced is directly proportional to: 1. Square of current ($I^2$). 2. Resistance ($R$). 3. Time ($t$) for which current flows.

content.exactPhrase: An electric fuse is a safety device connected in series with the circuit. It consists of a wire made of a metal/alloy with a low melting point. If current exceeds a safe limit, the fuse wire melts and breaks the circuit.

content.title: Electric Power ($P$)
content.body:
The rate at which electric energy is dissipated or consumed in a circuit.

**Formulas:** 
1. $P = VI$
2. $P = I^2R$
3. $P = \frac{V^2}{R}$
**Unit:** Watt (W). 
**Commercial Unit:** Kilowatt-hour (kWh). 
$1 kWh = 3.6 \times 10^6$ Joules.

content.question: An electric bulb is rated 220 V and 100 W. When it is operated on 110 V, the power consumed will be:
content.explanation: Resistance of the bulb $R = V^2/P = (220)^2/100 = 484 \Omega$. At 110 V, the new power $P' = V'^2/R = (110)^2/484 = 12100/484 = 25 W$. Note: Resistance remains constant even if voltage changes.
